member.name: T:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.WindowsScriptEngine
member.summary: Provides the base implementation for all Windows Script engines in a desktop environment.
member.remarks: Each Windows Script engine instance in a desktop environment has thread affinity and is bound to a during instantiation. Attempting to execute script code on a different thread results in an exception. Script delegates and event handlers are marshaled synchronously onto the correct thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.WindowsScriptEngine.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.WindowsScriptEngineFlags)
member.summary: Initializes a new Windows Script engine instance with the specified list of supported file name extensions.
member.param: The programmatic identifier (ProgID) of the Windows Script engine class.
A name to associate with the instance. Currently this name is used only as a label in presentation contexts such as debugger user interfaces.
A semicolon-delimited list of supported file name extensions.
A value that selects options for the operation.
member.remarks: The argument can be a class identifier (CLSID) in standard GUID format with braces (e.g., "{F414C260-6AC0-11CF-B6D1-00AA00BBBB58}").

member.name: P:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.WindowsScriptEngine.Dispatcher
member.summary: Gets the associated with the current script engine.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.JScriptEngine

member.remarks: Each Windows Script engine instance in a desktop environment has thread affinity and is bound to a during instantiation. Attempting to execute script code on a different thread results in an exception. Script delegates and event handlers are marshaled synchronously onto the correct thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.JScriptEngine.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new JScript engine instance.

member.summary: Initializes a new JScript engine instance with the specified name.

member.summary: Initializes a new JScript engine instance with the specified options.

member.summary: Initializes a new JScript engine instance with the specified name and options.

A value that selects options for the operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.JScriptEngine.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.WindowsScriptEngineFlags)
member.summary: Initializes a new JScript engine instance with the specified programmatic identifier, name, list of supported file name extensions, and options.
member.param: The programmatic identifier (ProgID) of the JScript engine class.
A name to associate with the instance. Currently this name is used only as a label in presentation contexts such as debugger user interfaces.
A semicolon-delimited list of supported file name extensions.
A value that selects options for the operation.
member.remarks: The argument can be a class identifier (CLSID) in standard GUID format with braces (e.g., "{F414C260-6AC0-11CF-B6D1-00AA00BBBB58}").

member.name: P:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.JScriptEngine.FileNameExtension
member.summary: Gets the script engine's recommended file name extension for script files.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.JScriptEngine.ExecuteCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Executes script code as a command.
member.param: The script command to execute.

remarks.para: This method is similar to but optimized for command consoles. The specified command must be limited to a single expression or statement. Script engines can override this method to customize command execution as well as the process of converting the result to a string for console output.
The version of this method attempts to use toString to convert the return value.

member.name: T:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.VBScriptEngine
member.summary: Represents an instance of the VBScript engine in a desktop environment.
member.remarks: Each Windows Script engine instance in a desktop environment has thread affinity and is bound to a during instantiation. Attempting to execute script code on a different thread results in an exception. Script delegates and event handlers are marshaled synchronously onto the correct thread.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.VBScriptEngine.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.String,Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.WindowsScriptEngineFlags)
member.summary: Initializes a new VBScript engine instance with the specified programmatic identifier, name, list of supported file name extensions, and options.
member.param: The programmatic identifier (ProgID) of the VBScript engine class.
A name to associate with the instance. Currently this name is used only as a label in presentation contexts such as debugger user interfaces.
A semicolon-delimited list of supported file name extensions.
A value that selects options for the operation.
member.remarks: The argument can be a class identifier (CLSID) in standard GUID format with braces (e.g., "{F414C260-6AC0-11CF-B6D1-00AA00BBBB58}").

member.name: P:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.VBScriptEngine.FileNameExtension
member.summary: Gets the script engine's recommended file name extension for script files.

member.name: M:Microsoft.ClearScript.Windows.VBScriptEngine.ExecuteCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Executes script code as a command.
member.param: The script command to execute.

remarks.para: This method is similar to but optimized for command consoles. The specified command must be limited to a single expression or statement. Script engines can override this method to customize command execution as well as the process of converting the result to a string for console output.

The version of this method supports both expressions and statements. If the specified command begins with "eval " (not case-sensitive), the engine executes the remainder as an expression and attempts to use CStr to convert the result value. Otherwise, it executes the command as a statement and does not return a value.
